revision.comment: Undid revision 746020924 by [[Special:Contributions/89.126.52.49|89.126.52.49]] ([[User talk:89.126.52.49|talk]]) but we normally know him as Suetonius
revision.text:
{{redirect|Boudicca|the cruise ship|MV Boudicca}} {{redirect|Boadicea}} {{for|the 2003 film also known as "Warrior Queen"|Boudica (film)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2012}} {{More footnotes|date=February 2016}} {{Infobox person | image = Queen Boudica by John Opie.jpg|right|thumb|''Boadicea Haranguing the Britons'' by [[John Opie]] | imagesize = | caption = Queen Boudica in [[John Opie]]'s painting ''Boadicea Haranguing the Britons'' | birth_date = | birth_place = [[Britannia]] | death_date = Circa 60 or 61 AD | death_place = [[Britannia]] | other_names = Boudicca, Boadicea, Buddug | occupation = Queen of the [[Iceni]] | spouse = [[Prasutagus]] }} '''Boudica''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|b|uː|d|ɨ|k|ə}}; alternative spellings: '''Boudicca''', '''Boudicea''', also known as '''Boadicea''' {{IPAc-en|b|oʊ|d|ɨ|ˈ|s|iː|ə}} and in [[Welsh language|Welsh]] as '''{{lang|cy|Buddug}}''' {{IPA-cy|ˈbɨ̞ðɨ̞ɡ|}}){{Cite book|author=[[John Davies (historian)|John Davies]]|title=A History of Wales|publisher=Penguin|year=1993 |location=London, UK|page=28|isbn=0-14-014581-8 }} (d. AD 60 or 61) was a queen of the [[Britons (historical)|British]] [[Celts|Celtic]] [[Iceni]] tribe who led an uprising against the occupying forces of the [[Roman Empire]]. Boudica's husband [[Prasutagus]] ruled as a nominally independent ally of Rome and left his kingdom jointly to his daughters and the [[Roman emperor]] in his will. However, when he died his will was ignored, and the kingdom was annexed. Boudica was flogged, her daughters [[wartime sexual violence|raped]],"iam primum uxor eius Boudicca verberibus adfecta et filiae stupro violatae sunt" Tacitus, Annales 14.31 previous imperial donations to influential Britons were confiscated and the Roman financier and philosopher [[Seneca the Younger|Seneca]] called in the loans he had forced on the reluctant Britons.Cassius Dio, [http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/E/Roman/Texts/Cassius_Dio/62*.html Epitome of Book LXII , 2] In AD 60 or 61, when the [[Governors of Roman Britain|Roman governor]] [[Gaius Suetonius Paulinus]] was campaigning on the island of [[Anglesey]] off the northwest coast of [[Wales]], Boudica led the Iceni, the [[Trinovantes]], and others in revolt.{{cite book|authors=Richard Hingley and Christina Unwin|title=Boudica: Iron Age Warrior Queen|publisher=Hambledon Continuum|edition=New|date=15 June 2006|isbn=978-1-85285-516-1|pages=44, 61}} They destroyed {{lang|la|[[Camulodunum]]}} (modern [[Colchester]]), earlier the capital of the [[Trinovantes]] but at that time a ''{{lang|la|[[colonia (Roman)|colonia]]}}'', a settlement for discharged Roman soldiers and site of a temple to the former Emperor [[Claudius]]. Upon hearing of the revolt, Suetonius hurried to {{lang|la|[[Londinium]]}} (modern [[London]]), the 20-year-old commercial settlement that was the rebels' next target. The Romans, having concluded that they lacked sufficient numbers to defend the settlement, evacuated and abandoned {{lang|la|Londinium}}. Boudica led 100,000 Iceni, Trinovantes, and others to fight {{lang|la|[[Legio IX Hispana|Legio IX ''Hispana'']]}}, and burned and destroyed {{lang|la|Londinium}} and {{lang|la|[[Verulamium]]}} (modern-day [[St Albans]]).{{cite book|author=N. Davies|title=The Isles: A History|year=2008|page=93}}{{cite book|author=S. Dando-Collins|title=Legions of Rome: The definitive history of every Roman legion|year=2012}} An estimated 70,000–80,000 Romans and British were killed in the three cities by those led by Boudica.[[Tacitus]], ''[[Annals (Tacitus)|Annals]]'' [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.02.0078%3Abook%3D14%3Achapter%3D33 14.33] Suetonius, meanwhile, regrouped his forces in the [[West Midlands (region)|West Midlands]], and, despite being heavily outnumbered, defeated the Britons in the [[Battle of Watling Street]]. The crisis caused [[Nero]] to consider withdrawing all Roman forces from Britain, but Suetonius' eventual victory over Boudica confirmed Roman control of the province. Boudica then either killed herself to avoid capture, or died of illness. The extant sources, [[Tacitus]]Tacitus, ''{{lang|la|[[Agricola (book)|Agricola]]}}'' [[Wikisource:Agricola#14|14-16]]; ''Annals'' [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/cgi-bin/ptext?lookup=Tac.+Ann.+14.29 14:29-39] and [[Cassius Dio]], differ.[[Cassius Dio]], ''Roman History'' [http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/E/Roman/Texts/Cassius_Dio/62*.html#1 62:1-12] Interest in these events revived in the [[English Renaissance]] and led to Boudica's fame in the [[Victorian era]].{{cite book|title=The Gentleman's Magazine|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MFZIAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA541|year=1854|publisher=W. Pickering|pages=541–}} Boudica has remained an important [[cultural icon|cultural symbol]] in the [[United Kingdom]]. In 2002, she was number 35 in the BBC's poll of the [[100 Greatest Britons]]. The absence of native British literature during the early part of the first millennium means that knowledge of Boudica's rebellion comes solely from the writings of the Romans.{{citation needed|date=February 2016}} ==Name== Boudica has been known by several versions of her name. [[Raphael Holinshed]] calls her '''Voadicia''', while [[Edmund Spenser]] calls her '''Bunduca''', a version of the name that was used in the popular Jacobean play ''[[Bonduca]]'', in 1612.[[Francis Beaumont]] and [[John Fletcher (playwright)|John Fletcher]], ''[http://www.bibliomania.com/0/6/1/1975/frameset.html Bonduca]'' [[William Cowper]]'s poem, ''Boadicea, an ode'' (1782) popularised an alternative version of the name.[[William Cowper]], ''[http://www.bartleby.com/41/320.html Boadicea, an ode]'' From the 19th century and much of the late 20th century, '''Boadicea''' was the most common version of the name, which is probably derived from a mistranscription when a manuscript of [[Tacitus]] was copied in the [[Middle Ages]]. Her name was clearly spelled '''Boudicca''' in the best manuscripts of Tacitus, but also {{lang|grc|Βουδουικα}}, {{lang|grc|Βουνδουικα}}, and {{lang|grc|Βοδουικα}} in the (later and probably secondary) [[epitome]] of [[Cassius Dio]]. The name is attested in inscriptions as '''Boudica''' in [[Lusitania]], '''Boudiga''' in [[Bordeaux]], and '''Bodicca''' in [[Algeria]].{{cite book|author=Graham Webster|title=Boudica: The British Revolt against Rome AD 60|year=1978}}{{cite book|author=[[Guy de la Bédoyère]]|url=http://www.romanbritain.freeserve.co.uk/Legions.htm|title=The Roman Army in Britain|accessdate=5 July 2005}} [[Kenneth H. Jackson|Kenneth Jackson]] concludes, based on later development of Welsh and Irish, that the name derives from the [[Proto-Celtic language|Proto-Celtic]] feminine adjective ''*boudīkā'', "victorious", that in turn is derived from the [[Celtic languages|Celtic]] word ''*boudā'', "victory" (cf. [[Irish language|Irish]] ''{{lang|ga|bua}}'' (Classical Irish ''{{lang|ghc|buadh}}''), ''Buaidheach'', [[Welsh language|Welsh]] ''{{lang|cy|buddugoliaeth}}''), and that the correct spelling of the name in [[Common Brittonic]] (the British Celtic language) is ''Boudica'', pronounced {{IPA-cel|bɒʊˈdiːkaː|}}. The closest English equivalent to the vowel in the first syllable is the ''ow'' in "bow-and-arrow".{{cite journal|author=[[Kenneth H. Jackson|Kenneth Jackson]]|title=Queen Boudica?|journal=Britannia|volume=10|year=1979|page=255|doi=10.2307/526060}} The modern English pronunciation is {{IPAc-en|ˈ|b|uː|d|ɪ|k|ə}},[http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/Boudicca Boudicca]. Dictionary.com. Dictionary.com Unabridged (v 1.1). Random House, Inc. (Retrieved 20 December 2007). and it has been suggested that the most comparable English name, in meaning only, would be "Victoria".{{cite book|author=Sir John Rhys|year=1908|publisher=General Literature Committee: Society for Promoting Christian Knowledge (Great Britain)|title=Early Britain, Celtic Britain|page=284|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VLpCAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA284&dq=Boudica&hl=en&ei=AAteTIuGMcG78gaQp-i9DQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0CDcQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=Boudica&f=false|accessdate=24 February 2016}} ==History== ===Background=== [[File:Map of the Territory of the Iceni.svg|thumb|Location of [[Iceni|Iceni territory]] in eastern England; modern county borders are shown.]] Tacitus and Cassius Dio agree that Boudica was of [[royal family|royal]] descent. Dio describes her as "possessed of greater intelligence than often belongs to women." He also describes her as tall, with [[tawny (color)|tawny]] hair hanging down to below her waist, a harsh voice and a piercing glare. He notes that she habitually wore a large golden necklace (perhaps a [[torc]]), a colourful tunic, and a thick cloak fastened by a [[brooch]].{{cite web|url=http://www.academia.edu/548341/Boudica_Cartimandua_Messalina_and_Agrippina_the_Younger._Independent_Women_of_Power_and_the_Gendered_Rhetoric_of_Roman_History|title=Boudica, Cartimandua, Messalina and Agrippina the Younger. Independent Women of Power and the Gendered Rhetoric of Roman History|author=Peter Keegan|work=academia.edu|accessdate=24 February 2016}}The term ''{{lang|grc-Latn|xanthotrichos}}'' translated in this passage as red–brown or tawny can also mean auburn, or a shade ''short'' of brown, but most translators now agree a colour in between light and browny red — '''tawny''' — {{cite book|title=Boudica and her stories: narrative transformations of a warrior queen|author=Carolyn D. Williams|publisher=University of Delaware Press|year=2009|page=62}} Boudicca’s husband, [[Prasutagus]], was the king of the Iceni, a people who inhabited roughly what is now Norfolk. The Iceni initially voluntarily allied with Rome following Claudius's conquest of Southern Britain AD 43. They were proud of their independence, and had revolted in AD 47 when the then Roman governor [[Publius Ostorius Scapula]] planned to disarm all the peoples in the area of Britain under Roman control following a number of local uprisings. Ostorius defeated them and went on to put down other uprisings around Britain.Tacitus, ''The Annals'', 12.31-32 The Iceni remained independent. Tacitus first mentioned Prasutagus when he wrote about Boudica’s rebellion. We do not know whether he became the king after the mentioned defeat of the Iceni. The client relationship with Rome ended after the end of the rebellion.{{Cite web|url=http://penelope.uchicago.edu/~grout/encyclopaedia_romana/britannia/boudica/boudicanrevolt.html|title=Boudica|website=penelope.uchicago.edu|access-date=2016-10-14}} Tacitus wrote "The Icenian king Prasutagus, celebrated for his long prosperity, had named the emperor his heir, together with his two daughters; an act of deference which he thought would place his kingdom and household beyond the risk of injury. The result was contrary — so much so that his kingdom was pillaged by centurions, his household by slaves; as though they had been prizes of war." He added that Boudica was lashed and her two daughters were raped and that the estates of the leading Iceni men were confiscated.Tacitus, ''The Annals'', 14.31 Cassius Dio wrote: "An excuse for the war was found in the confiscation of the sums of money that Claudius had given to the foremost Britons; for these sums, as [[Decianus Catus]], the procurator of the island maintained, were to be paid back." He also said that another reasons was "the fact that [[Seneca the Younger|Seneca]], in the hope of receiving a good rate of interest, had lent to the islanders 40,000,000 sesterces that they did not want, and had afterwards called in this loan all at once and had resorted to severe measures in exacting it."Cassius Dio, ''Roman History'', 62.2 Tacitus did not say why Prasutagus’ naming the emperor as his heir as well as his daughters was meant to avert the risk of injury. He did not explain why the Romans pillaged the kingdom, why they took the lands of the chiefs or why Boudica was flogged and her daughters were raped. Cassius Dio did not mention any of this. He said that the cause of the rebellion was the decision of the procurator of Britain (the chief financial officer) and Seneca (an advisor of the emperor Nero) to call in Prasutagus’ debts and the harsh measures which were taken to collect them. Tacitus does not mention these events. However, he wrote: "Alarmed by this disaster and by the fury of the province which he had goaded into war by his rapacity, the procurator Catus crossed over into Gaul."Tacitus, ''The Annals'', 14.32 It has to be noted that this was happening while the governor of Britain, Gaius Suetonius Paulinus, was away fighting in North Wales. We do not know whether he approved of these actions. We do not know who the centurions who pillaged the kingdom were and who sent them. The text of Cassius Dio seems to suggest that Seneca, who was a private citizen, was responsible for the violence. It is unlikely that a legion was sent to land of the Iceni as two of them were fighting at the island of Anglesey and the other two were stationed at their garrisons. Tacitus said that "It was against the veterans that their hatred was most intense. For these new settlers in the colony of Camulodunum drove people out of their houses, ejected them from their farms, called them captives and slaves …" ===Boudica's uprising=== In AD 60 or 61, while the current governor, [[Gaius Suetonius Paulinus]], was leading a campaign against the island of {{lang|la|Mona}} (modern [[Anglesey]]) in the north of Wales, which was a refuge for British rebels and a stronghold of the [[druid]]s, the Iceni conspired with their neighbours the Trinovantes, amongst others, to revolt. Boudica was chosen as their leader. According to Tacitus, they drew inspiration from the example of [[Arminius]], the prince of the [[Cherusci]] who had driven the Romans out of Germany in AD 9, and their own ancestors who had driven [[Julius Caesar]] from Britain.Tacitus, ''{{lang|la|Agricola}}'' [[Wikisource:Agricola#15|15]] Dio says that at the outset Boudica employed a form of [[divination]], releasing a [[hare]] from the folds of her dress and interpreting the direction in which it ran, and invoked [[Andraste]], a British [[goddess]] of [[Victoria (mythology)|victory]]. The rebels' first target was {{lang|la|[[Camulodunum#Iceni Revolt|Camulodunum]]}} ([[Colchester]]), the former Trinovantian capital and, at that time, a Roman ''{{lang|la|[[colonia (Roman)|colonia]]}}''. The Roman veterans who had been settled there mistreated the locals and a temple to the former emperor [[Claudius]] had been erected there at local expense, making the city a focus for resentment. The Roman inhabitants sought reinforcements from the procurator, Catus Decianus, but he sent only two hundred [[auxiliaries (Roman military)|auxiliary troops]]. Boudica's army fell on the poorly defended city and destroyed it, besieging the last defenders in the temple for two days before it fell. [[Archaeology|Archaeologists]] have shown that the city was methodically demolished.{{cite news |author=Jason Burke |url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2000/dec/03/jasonburke.theobserver |title=Dig uncovers Boudicca's brutal streak |work=[[The Observer]] |date=3 December 2000 |accessdate=5 July 2016}} The future governor [[Quintus Petillius Cerialis]], then commanding the [[Legio IX Hispana|Legio IX ''Hispana'']], attempted to relieve the city, but suffered an [[Massacre of the Ninth Legion|overwhelming defeat]]. His infantry was wiped out—only the commander and some of his cavalry escaped. The location of this famous destruction of the {{lang|la|Legio IX}} is now claimed by some to be the village of [[Great Wratting]], in Suffolk, which lies in the Stour Valley on the Icknield Way West of Colchester, and by a village in Essex.{{Cite web|title=Haverhill From the Iron Age to 1899|url=http://www.stedmundsbury.gov.uk/sebc/visit/hh-to-1899.cfm|publisher=St. Edmundsbury Borough Council|accessdate=24 February 2016}} After this defeat, Catus Decianus fled to [[Gaul]]. When news of the rebellion reached him, Suetonius hurried along [[Watling Street]] through hostile territory to {{lang|la|Londinium}}. {{lang|la|Londinium}} was a relatively new settlement, founded after the conquest of AD 43, but it had grown to be a thriving commercial centre with a population of travellers, traders, and, probably, Roman officials. Suetonius considered giving battle there, but considering his lack of numbers and chastened by Petillius's defeat, decided to sacrifice the city to save the province.
Alarmed by this disaster and by the fury of the province which he had goaded into war by his rapacity, the procurator Catus crossed over into Gaul. Suetonius, however, with wonderful resolution, marched amidst a hostile population to Londinium, which, though undistinguished by the name of a colony, was much frequented by a number of merchants and trading vessels. Uncertain whether he should choose it as a seat of war, as he looked round on his scanty force of soldiers, and remembered with what a serious warning the rashness of Petilius had been punished, he resolved to save the province at the cost of a single town. Nor did the tears and weeping of the people, as they implored his aid, deter him from giving the signal of departure and receiving into his army all who would go with him. Those who were chained to the spot by the weakness of their sex, or the infirmity of age, or the attractions of the place, were cut off by the enemy.— Tacitus
Londinium was abandoned to the rebels who burnt it down, slaughtering anyone who had not evacuated with Suetonius. Archaeology shows a thick red layer of burnt debris covering coins and pottery dating before AD 60 within the bounds of Roman Londinium;{{cite book|author=George Patrick Welch|title=Britannia: The Roman Conquest & Occupation of Britain|year=1963|page=107}} while Roman-era skulls found in the [[Walbrook]] in 2013 were potentially linked to victims of the rebels.{{cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/science/2013/oct/02/roman-skulls-crossrail-london-boudicca|title=Roman skulls found during Crossrail dig in London may be Boudicca victims|author=Maev Kennedy |work=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=24 February 2016}} {{lang|la|[[Verulamium]]}} ([[St Albans]]) was next to be destroyed. In the three settlements destroyed, between seventy and eighty thousand people are said to have been killed. Tacitus says that the Britons had no interest in taking or selling prisoners, only in slaughter by [[gibbet]], fire, or cross.{{citation needed|date=February 2016}} Dio's account gives more detail; that the noblest women were impaled on spikes and had their breasts cut off and sewn to their mouths, "to the accompaniment of sacrifices, banquets, and wanton behaviour" in sacred places, particularly the groves of Andraste.{{citation needed|date=February 2016}} ===Romans rally=== {{See also|Battle of Watling Street}} While Boudica's army continued their assault in Verulamium (St. Albans), Suetonius regrouped his forces. According to Tacitus, he amassed a force including his own [[Legio XIV Gemina|Legio XIV ''Gemina'']], some ''vexillationes'' (detachments) of the [[Legio XX Valeria Victrix|XX ''Valeria Victrix'']], and any available auxiliaries.Tacitus, ''Annals'' [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/cgi-bin/ptext?lookup=Tac.+Ann.+14.34 14.34] The [[prefect]] of {{lang|la|[[Legio II Augusta|Legio II ''Augusta'']]}}, [[Poenius Postumus]], stationed near [[Exeter]], ignored the call,Tacitus, ''Annals'' [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/cgi-bin/ptext?lookup=Tac.+Ann.+14.37 14.37] and a fourth legion, {{lang|la|[[Legio IX Hispana|IX ''Hispana'']]}}, had been routed trying to relieve {{lang|la|Camulodunum}},Tacitus, ''Annals'' [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/cgi-bin/ptext?lookup=Tac.+Ann.+14.32 14.32] but nonetheless the governor was able to call on almost ten thousand men. Suetonius took a stand at an unidentified location, probably in the [[West Midlands (region)|West Midlands]] somewhere along the [[Roman road]] now known as [[Watling Street]], in a [[defile (geography)|defile]] with a wood behind him — but his men were heavily outnumbered. Dio says that, even if they were lined up one deep, they would not have extended the length of Boudica's line. By now the rebel forces were said to have numbered 230,000. However, this number should be treated with scepticism — Dio's account is known only from a late [[epitome]], and ancient sources commonly exaggerate enemy numbers. Boudica exhorted her troops from her [[chariot]], her daughters beside her. Tacitus gives her a short speech in which she presents herself not as an [[aristocracy (class)|aristocrat]] avenging her lost wealth, but as an ordinary person, avenging her lost freedom, her battered body, and the abused chastity of her daughters. She said their cause was just, and the deities were on their side; the one legion that had dared to face them had been destroyed. She, a woman, was resolved to win or die; if the men wanted to live in slavery, that was their choice. However, the lack of manoeuvrability of the British forces, combined with lack of open-field tactics to command these numbers, put them at a disadvantage to the Romans, who were skilled at open combat due to their superior equipment and discipline. Also, the narrowness of the field meant that Boudica could put forth only as many troops as the Romans could at a given time.{{citation needed|date=February 2016}} First, the Romans stood their ground and used volleys of ''{{lang|la|[[pilum|pila]]}}'' (heavy javelins) to kill thousands of Britons who were rushing toward the Roman lines. The Roman soldiers, who had now used up their ''{{lang|la|pila}}'', were then able to engage Boudica's second wave in the open. As the Romans advanced in a [[flying wedge|wedge]] formation, the Britons attempted to flee, but were impeded by the presence of their own families, whom they had stationed in a ring of wagons at the edge of the battlefield, and were slaughtered. This is not the first instance of this tactic — the women of the [[Cimbri]], in the [[Battle of Vercellae]] against [[Gaius Marius]], were stationed in a line of wagons and acted as a last line of defence.[[Florus]], ''Epitome of Roman History'' [[Wikisource:Epitome of Roman History/Book 1#38|1.38]] [[Ariovistus]] of the [[Suebi]] is reported to have done the same thing in [[Battle of Vosges (58 BC)|his battle]] against [[Julius Caesar]].[[Julius Caesar]], ''{{lang|la|[[Commentarii de Bello Gallico]]}}'' [[Wikisource:Commentaries on the Gallic War/Book1#51|1.51]] Tacitus reports that "according to one report almost eighty thousand Britons fell" compared with only four hundred Romans. According to Tacitus in his ''Annals'', Boudica poisoned herself, though in the ''{{lang|la|Agricola}}'' which was written almost twenty years prior he mentions nothing of suicide and attributes the end of the revolt to ''{{lang|la|socordia}}'' ("indolence"); Dio says she fell sick and died and then was given a lavish burial; though this may be a convenient way to remove her from the story. Considering Dio must have read Tacitus, it is worth noting he mentions nothing about suicide (which was also how Postumus and Nero ended their lives). Postumus, on hearing of the Roman victory, fell on his sword. [[Catus Decianus]], who had fled to Gaul, was replaced by [[Gaius Julius Alpinus Classicianus]]. Suetonius conducted punitive operations, but criticism by Classicianus led to an investigation headed by [[Nero]]'s [[freedman]] [[Polyclitus (freedman)|Polyclitus]]. Fearing Suetonius's actions would provoke further rebellion, Nero replaced the governor with the more conciliatory [[Publius Petronius Turpilianus]].Tacitus, ''Annals'' [[wikisource:The Annals (Tacitus)/Book 14#39|14.39]] The historian [[Suetonius|Gaius Suetonius Tranquillus]] tells us the crisis had almost persuaded Nero to abandon Britain.[[Suetonius]], ''Nero'' [http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/E/Roman/Texts/Suetonius/12Caesars/Nero*.html#18 18], [http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/E/Roman/Texts/Suetonius/12Caesars/Nero*.html#39 39-40] No historical records tell us what had happened to Boudica's two daughters; whether they had fallen in the battle or commited suicide by taking poison just like their mother is uncertain. ===Location of her defeat=== The location of Boudica's defeat is unknown. Most historians{{citation needed|date=March 2014}} favour a site in the [[West Midlands (county)|West Midlands]], somewhere along the Roman road now known as [[Watling Street]]. Kevin K. Carroll suggests a site close to [[High Cross, Leicestershire|High Cross]] in [[Leicestershire]], on the junction of Watling Street and the [[Fosse Way]], which would have allowed the {{lang|la|[[Legio II Augusta|Legio II ''Augusta'']]}}, based at [[Exeter]], to rendezvous with the rest of Suetonius's forces, had they not failed to do so.{{cite journal |author=Kevin K. Carroll |title=The Date of Boudicca's Revolt |journal=Britannia |volume=10 |year=1979 |pages=197–202 |doi=10.2307/526056 }} [[Manduessedum]] ([[Mancetter]]), near the modern town of [[Atherstone]] in [[Warwickshire]], has also been suggested,{{cite book |author=[[Sheppard Frere]] |title=Britannia: A History of Roman Britain |year=1987 |page=73 }} as has "The Rampart" near [[Messing]] in [[Essex]], according to legend.{{cite web |publisher=Messing-cum-Inworth Community Website |url=http://messing-cum-inworth-pc.gov.uk/messVill.htm |title=Messing Village }} More recently, a discovery of Roman artefacts in [[Kings Norton]] close to [[Birmingham military history|Metchley Camp]] has suggested another possibility,{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/england/west_midlands/5016126.stm |title=Is Boudicca buried in Birmingham? |work=[[BBC News Online]] |date=25 May 2006 |accessdate=9 September 2006 }} and a thorough examination of a stretch of Watling Street between St. Albans, Boudica's last known location, and the Fosse Way junction has suggested the Cuttle Mill area of [[Paulerspury]] in Northamptonshire, which has [[topography]] very closely matching that described by Tacitus of the scene of the battle.{{cite web|url=http://paulerspury.org/content/view/18/49/ |title=ﾓﾊﾞｲﾙ版 |work=paulerspury.org |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100819032234/http://paulerspury.org/content/view/18/49 |archivedate=19 August 2010 }} In 2009 it was suggested that the Iceni were returning to East Anglia along the [[Icknield Way]] when they encountered the Roman army in the vicinity of [[Arbury Banks, Hertfordshire|Arbury Bank]], Hertfordshire.{{cite journal |author=Grahame Appleby |year=2009 |title=The Boudican Revolt: Countdown to Defeat |journal=Hertfordshire Archaeology and History |volume=16 |pages=57–66 |url=http://www.researchgate.net/publication/280564223_The_Boudican_Revolt_Countdown_to_defeat|accessdate=24 February 2016}} In March 2010, evidence was published suggesting the site may be located at [[Church Stowe]], Northamptonshire.{{cite web|url=http://www.craftpegg.com/Battle_Church_Stowe_CP.pdf|format=PDF|title=Landscape Analysis and Appraisal Church Stowe, Northamptonshire, as a Candidate Site for the Battle of Watling Street|website=craftpegg.com|accessdate=24 February 2016}} ===Historical sources=== Tacitus, the most important Roman historian of this period, took a particular interest in Britain as his father-in-law [[Gnaeus Julius Agricola]] served there three times (and was the subject of his first book). Agricola was a military tribune under Suetonius Paulinus, which almost certainly gave Tacitus an eyewitness source for Boudica's revolt. Cassius Dio's account is only known from an [[epitome]], and his sources are uncertain. He is generally agreed to have based his account on that of Tacitus, but he simplifies the sequence of events and adds details, such as the calling in of loans, that Tacitus does not mention.{{citation needed|date=February 2016}} [[Gildas]], in his 6th century ''{{lang|la|[[De Excidio et Conquestu Britanniae]]}}'', may have been alluding to Boudica when he wrote "A treacherous lioness butchered the governors who had been left to give fuller voice and strength to the endeavours of Roman rule". ==Cultural depictions== ===Boudica and King's Cross=== The area of [[King's Cross, London]] was previously a village known as Battle Bridge which was an ancient crossing of the [[River Fleet]]. The original name of the bridge was Broad Ford Bridge. The name "Battle Bridge" led to a tradition that this was the site of a major battle between the Romans and the Iceni tribe led by Boudica.{{cite web |url=http://www.british-history.ac.uk/report.aspx?compid=45097 |title=Highbury, Upper Holloway and King's Cross |work=Old and New London: Volume 2 |author=Walter Thornbury |authorlink=George Walter Thornbury |year=1878 |pages=273–279 |accessdate=11 November 2010 |publisher=British History Online }} The tradition is not supported by any historical evidence and is rejected by modern historians. However, [[Lewis Spence]]'s 1937 book ''Boadicea — warrior queen of the Britons'' went so far as to include a map showing the positions of the opposing armies. There is a belief that she was buried between platforms 9 and 10 in [[London King's Cross railway station|King's Cross station]] in London, England. There is no evidence for this and it is probably a post-[[World War II]] invention.{{cite web |title=The "Warrior Queen" under Platform 9 |url=http://www.museumoflondon.org.uk/English/Learning/Learningonline/features/roman/roman_london_7.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090301192533/http://www.museumoflondon.org.uk/English/Learning/Learningonline/features/roman/roman_london_7.htm |publisher= Museum of London |archivedate=1 March 2009 |accessdate=13 August 2011 }} ===History and literature=== By the [[Middle Ages]] Boudica was forgotten. She makes no appearance in [[Bede]]'s work, the ''{{lang|la|[[Historia Brittonum]]}}'', the ''{{lang|cy|[[Mabinogion]]}}'' or [[Geoffrey of Monmouth]]'s ''[[History of the Kings of Britain]]''. But the rediscovery of the works of Tacitus during the Renaissance allowed [[Polydore Vergil]] to reintroduce her into British history as "Voadicea" in 1534.{{cite book |title=Polydore Vergil's English History, Book 2 |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=hSAIAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA59 |pages=69–72 }} Raphael Holinshed also included her story in his ''Chronicles'' (1577), based on Tacitus and Dio,[[Raphael Holinshed]], ''Chronicles'': History of England [http://www.gutenberg.org/files/16536/16536-h/16536-h.htm#page494 4.9-13] and inspired [[William Shakespeare|Shakespeare's]] younger contemporaries [[Francis Beaumont]] and [[John Fletcher (playwright)|John Fletcher]] to write a play, ''[[Bonduca]]'', in 1610. [[William Cowper]] wrote a popular poem, "Boadicea, an ode", in 1782. It was in the [[Victorian era]] that Boudica's fame took on legendary proportions as [[Queen Victoria]] came to be seen as Boudica's "namesake", their names being identical in meaning. Victoria's [[Poet Laureate]], [[Alfred, Lord Tennyson]], wrote a poem, "Boadicea", and several ships were named [[HMS Boadicea|after her]].[[Alfred, Lord Tennyson]], ''[http://oldpoetry.com/opoem/8721-Alfred-Lord-Tennyson-Boadicea Boadicea]'' ===Art=== * The artwork ''[[The Dinner Party]]'' by Judy Chicago features a place setting for Boudica.[https://www.brooklynmuseum.org/eascfa/dinner_party/place_settings Place Settings]. Brooklyn Museum. Retrieved on 2015-08-06. ===Audio dramas=== * The [[Big Finish Productions]] ''[[Doctor Who]]'' audio play ''[[The Wrath of the Iceni]]'' (2012), starring [[Tom Baker]], takes place during Boudica's uprising against the Romans. Boudica is portrayed by British actress [[Ella Kenion]].[http://www.bigfinish.com/103-Doctor-Who-The-Wrath-of-the-Iceni''The Wrath of the Iceni''] at bigfinish.com. * Heirloom Audio Productions' audio theater adaption of G.A. Henty's novel, ''Beric the Briton'', starring [[Brian Blessed]], [[Brian Cox (actor)|Brian Cox]], and [[John Rhys-Davies]] features Queen Boadicea during the first portion of the drama. Her character is played by British [[Actresses (film)|actress]], [[Honeysuckle Weeks]]. ===Comics=== She has also appeared in several comic book series, including: *''{{lang|ga|[[Sláine (comics)|Sláine]]}}'', which featured two runs, titled "Demon Killer" and "Queen of Witches" giving a free interpretation of Boudica's story *The [[DC Comics]] character [[Boodikka]], a member of the [[Green Lantern Corps]], was named after Boudica. ===Films=== Boudica has been the subject of multiple films: * ''[[Boadicea (film)|Boadicea]]'' (1927) is a feature film, wherein she was portrayed by [[Phyllis Neilson-Terry]],{{IMDb title |id=0018713 |title=Boadicea (1927) }} * ''[[The Viking Queen]]'' (1967) is a [[Hammer Films]] adventure movie set in ancient Britain, in which the role of Queen Salina is based upon the historical figure of Boudica. *''[[Boudica (film)|Boudica]]'' (2003; ''Warrior Queen'' in the US) is a UK [[television|TV]] film written by [[Andrew Davies (writer)|Andrew Davies]] and starring [[Alex Kingston]] as Boudica.{{IMDb title |id=0338806 |title=Warrior Queen (2003) }} * A History Channel documentary production is entitled ''Warrior Queen Boudica'' (2006). ===Games=== * In ''[[Civilization II]]'', ''[[Civilization IV: Beyond the Sword]]'' and ''[[Civilization V: Gods & Kings]]'', Boudicca is leader of the Celtic tribe. * She appears as a character in the heavily fictionalized 2013 video game ''[[Ryse: Son of Rome]]''. * She appears in the tutorial of [[Rise of Nations]]. ===Multimedia fiction=== * In the fictional world of ''[[Ghosts of Albion]]'', Queen Bodicea is one of three Ghosts who once were mystical protectors of Albion and assists the current protectors with advice and knowledge. ===Music=== * Irish singer and musician [[Enya]] has a song titled "Boadicea" on her first album ''[[Enya (album)|Enya]]'' (also released as ''The Celts''). The song was later sampled by various other artists. ===Novels=== Boudica's story is the subject of several novels, including books by J. F. Broxholme (a pseudonym of [[Duncan Kyle]]), [[Pauline Gedge]], [[Alan Gold (author)|Alan Gold]], [[Mary Mackie]], [[Diana L. Paxson]], [[Simon Scarrow]], [[Manda Scott]], [[George Shipway]], [[Rosemary Sutcliff]], and [[David Wishart]]. *In Chapter XXI of [[Lindsey Davis]]' first Falco mystery, ''[[The Silver Pigs]]'', Falco briefly recounts the story of the rebellion from his perspective, having served in the Second legion of the Roman army, under the "peabrained" Camp Prefect, Poenius Postumus. Throughout the book, he references the shame of having served under that illustrious leader and of being involved in that event. *She plays a central role in the first part of [[G. A. Henty]]'s novel ''[[Beric the Briton]]'' * In ''[[The Mauritius Command]]'' by [[Patrick O'Brian]], the fourth novel of the [[Aubrey-Maturin series]], Jack Aubrey is given command of the {{HMS|Boadicea|1797|6}}. * [[Tim Powers]]' vampire novel ''Hide Me Among the Graves'' (2012) depicts Boadicea as one of the two head vampires menacing Victorian Europe. * [[Henry Treece]]'s children's novel, ''The Queen's Brooch'', is set during her rebellion. *One of the viewpoint characters of [[Ian Watson (author)|Ian Watson]]'s novel ''Oracle'' is an eyewitness to her defeat. *In [[Harry Turtledove]]'s [[alternate history]] novel ''[[Ruled Britannia]]'', Boudicca is the subject of a play written by [[William Shakespeare]] to incite the people of Britain to revolt against Spanish conquerors. ===Statue=== {{main article|Boadicea and Her Daughters}} [[Image:boudiccastatue.jpg|thumb|''[[Boadicea and Her Daughters]]'' by [[Thomas Thornycroft]], standing near [[Westminster Millennium Pier|Westminster Pier]], London]] [[File:Boudica (Aldaron).jpg|thumb||
Detail of [[Thomas Thornycroft]]'s ''Boadicea''
]] A statue of [[Boadicea and Her Daughters|Boudica with her daughters]] in her [[war chariot]] (ahistorically furnished with [[scythed chariot|scythes]] after the [[Achaemenid Empire|Persian]] fashion) was executed by [[Thomas Thornycroft]] over the 1850s and 1860s with the encouragement of [[Prince Albert, Prince Consort|Prince Albert]], who lent his horses for use as models.{{cite book |title=Images of Women in Peace & War: Cross-Cultural & Historical Perspectives |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=SCUbpgTPeOgC&pg=PA53 |p=53 |publisher=Macmillan Press |date=1987 |location=London |chapter=Boadicea: Warrior, Mother, and Myth |last=Macdonald |first=Sharon| isbn=0-299-11764-2 }} Thornycroft exhibited the head separately in 1864. It was cast in bronze in 1902, 17 years after Thornycroft's death, by his son [[John Isaac Thornycroft|Sir John]], who presented it to the [[London County Council]]. They erected it on a plinth on the [[Victoria Embankment]] next to [[Westminster Bridge]] and the [[Palace of Westminster|Houses of Parliament]], inscribed with the following lines from Cowper's poem:
Regions Caesar never knew Thy posterity shall sway.
Ironically, the great anti-imperialist rebel was now identified with the head of the [[British Empire]], and her statue{{Cite web |url=http://www.culture24.org.uk/history+%2526+heritage/war+%2526+conflict/pre%252d20th+century+conflict/tra22669 |title=Battlefield Britain — Boudicca's revolt against the Romans |author=Corinne Field |date=30 April 2006 |publisher=Culture24 |accessdate=8 December 2009}} stood guard over the city she razed to the ground. ===Television=== ====Series==== * Boudicca is a character in the animated series ''[[Gargoyles (TV series)|Gargoyles]]''.[http://www.dracandros.com/Jebgarg/tge/boudicca.htm ''Boudicca''] at The Gargoyles Encyclopedia. *She was the subject of a 1978 British TV series, ''[[Warrior Queen]]'', starring [[Siân Phillips]] as Boudica. ====Episodes==== * The British television series ''[[Bonekickers]]'', dedicated an hour to Boudica in the episode named "The Eternal Fire" (July 2008).{{IMDb title |id=1260754 |title="Bonekickers" The Eternal Fire (TV Episode 2008) }} Various female politicians, including former [[Prime Minister]] of New Zealand [[Helen Clark]], have been called Boadicea.{{cite web |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/business/news/article.cfm?c_id=3&objectid=10540015 |title=Gladiator v Boadicea: No contest? |author=Fran O'Sullivan |date=30 October 2008 |work=[[The New Zealand Herald]] |accessdate=11 September 2011 }} *[[Jennifer Ward-Lealand]] portrayed Boudica in an episode of ''[[Xena: Warrior Princess]]'' titled "The Deliverer" (1997). * [[Martha Howe-Douglas]] and [[Lorna Watson]] played Boudica in ''[[Horrible Histories (2009 TV series)|Horrible Histories]]''. * [[Kirsty Mitchell]] played Boudica in an episode of the History Channel's ''[[Barbarians Rising]]'' series titled "Revenge" (2016). The episode depicts Boudica as dying in battle after being run through by a Roman soldier, and one of her daughters being killed by a [[cavalryman]], though the website for the series notes Tacitus' version of her suicide.{{cite web |url=http://www.history.com/news/ask-history/who-was-boudica |title=Who was Boudica? - Ask History |author=Sarah Pruitt |date=31 May 2016 |accessdate=14 July 2016 |website=History.com |publisher=[[A&E Networks]]}} ===Other cultural references=== * In 2003, a [[long terminal repeat]] [[retrotransposon]] from the [[genome]] of the human [[Schistosoma|blood fluke]] ''Schistosoma mansoni'' was named "Boudicca".{{cite journal |authors=Copeland CS, Brindley PJ, Heyers O, Michael SF, Johnston DA, Williams DL, Ivens AC, Kalinna BH |title=''Boudica'', a retrovirus-like long terminal repeat retrotransposon from the genome of the human blood fluke ''Schistosoma mansoni'' |journal=Journal of Virology |date=June 2003 |volume=77 |issue=11 |pages=6153–66 |doi=10.1128/jvi.77.11.6153-6166.2003}}{{cite journal |authors=Copeland CS, Heyers O, Kalinna BH, Bachmair A, Stadler PF, Hofacker IL, Brindley PJ |title=Structural and evolutionary analysis of the transcribed sequence of ''Boudicca'', a ''Schistosoma mansoni'' retrotransposon |journal=Gene |year=2004 |volume=329 |pages=103–114 |doi=10.1016/j.gene.2003.12.023}} The Boudicca retrotransposon, a high-copy retroviral-like element, was the first mobile genetic element of this type to be discovered in ''S. mansoni''. ==See also== * {{lang|cy|[[Gwenllian ferch Gruffydd]]}} * [[List of women BBC; 6 August 2004 * [http://www.roman-britain.org/tribes/iceni.htm Iceni] at [http://www.roman-britain.org Roman-Britain.org] * [http://www.romans-in-britain.org.uk/clb_tribe_iceni.htm Iceni] at [http://www.romans-in-britain.org.uk/ Romans in Britain] * [http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1519322/Boadicea-may-have-had-her-chips-on-site-of-McDonalds.html ''Boadicea may have had her chips on site of McDonald's'' by Nick Britten] * [http://www.pbs.org/wgbh/masterpiece/warriorqueen/ PBS Boudica / Warrior Queen website] * [http://www.cbc.ca/arts/features/kingarthur/ Warrior queens and blind critics] - article on the 2004 film ''[[King Arthur (film)|King Arthur]]'' which discusses Boudica * [http://www.projectcontinua.org/boadicea/ Project Continua: Biography of Boadicea] * [http://www.channel4.com/history/microsites/H/history/a-b/boud3.html Channel 4 History - In Boudica's Footsteps] * {{Cite EB9|wstitle=Boadicea|volume=3 |short=x}} {{Ancient Roman Wars}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Boudica| ]] [[Category:Year of birth unknown]] [[Category:61 deaths]] [[Category:Ancient people who committed suicide]] [[Category:Female suicides]] [[Category:Pagans]] [[Category:Women in 1st-century warfare]] [[Category:Briton rulers]] [[Category:Queens regnant in the British Isles]] [[Category:Rebellions against the Roman Empire]] [[Category:1st-century conflicts]] [[Category:Ancient Celtic women]] [[Category:People from Norfolk]] [[Category:1st-century female rulers]] [[Category:1st-century monarchs in Europe]] [[Category:Whipping]] [[Category:1st century in the Roman Empire]] [[Category:Iceni]] [[Category:Wartime sexual violence]] [[Category:Women in European warfare]]
